notes.title: Essentials of a Valid Contract (Contract Act, 1872)
notes.content: Define contract (offer, acceptance, consideration, capacity, free consent, lawful object). Master sections on proposal/acceptance (S.2–9), void/voidable agreements, and performance/discharge for MCQs and long questions.
keyTakeaways: All contracts are agreements, but not all agreements are contracts (S.2).
Free consent (coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation, mistake) drives voidability.
Discharge can occur by performance, agreement, impossibility, breach, and operation of law.

notes.title: Free Consent: Coercion, Undue Influence, Fraud, Misrepresentation, Mistake
notes.content: CSS repeatedly asks to distinguish grounds that vitiate consent and their legal effects (void vs. voidable). Prepare illustrations and case-style reasoning.
keyTakeaways: Coercion vs. undue influence differ by source of pressure and relationship.
Fraud/misrepresentation: remedy often rescission + damages (where applicable).
Bilateral vs. unilateral mistake affects validity differently.

resources.title: Contract Act — Consent & Free Consent provisions

notes.title: Sale of Goods: Conditions vs. Warranties, Caveat Emptor, Passing of Property, Unpaid Seller
notes.content: Focus on when title passes, implied conditions (merchantable quality, fitness), and unpaid seller's rights (lien, stoppage-in-transit, resale).
keyTakeaways: Distinguish condition/warranty; breach of condition allows rejection.
Caveat emptor has key exceptions (implied terms, reliance).
Timing rules determine risk/title transfer and exam hypotheticals.

resources.title: Sale of Goods Act, 1930 (Punjab Laws PDF)

notes.title: Partnership: Formation, Implied Authority, Minor Partner, Dissolution
notes.content: CSS often tests partnership vs. company, rights/obligations inter se, and limitations on implied authority. Prepare dissolution modes and consequences.
keyTakeaways: Partnership is a relation to share profits carried on by all or any acting for all.
Implied authority excludes certain acts unless custom/usage extends it.
Minor can be admitted to benefits, not full partnership.

notes.title: Company Law: Separate Personality, Memorandum & Articles, Meetings, Directors, Charges
notes.content: Move beyond definitions to governance and remedies: alteration of constitutional documents, statutory meetings/reports, directors' qualifications/liabilities, fixed vs. floating charges, minority protection.
keyTakeaways: Companies Act 2017 replaced the 1984 Ordinance; rely on current sections.
Doctrine of indoor management protects third parties dealing with company.
Understand incorporation regulations and SECP circulars for compliance angles.

notes.title: Negotiable Instruments: PN, BoE, Cheque; Presumptions, Discharge, Dishonour
notes.content: Master statutory presumptions, parties' liabilities, endorsement/negotiation, and notice of dishonour. Crossing of cheques and payment in due course show up often.
keyTakeaways: Section 13 recognizes PN, BoE, cheque; presumptions favor holder in due course.
Discharge of maker/acceptor/endorser tested via modes and timelines.
Compare inland vs. foreign instruments; crossing rules for cheques.

notes.title: Arbitration: Agreement, Appointment, Powers, Award & Setting Aside
notes.content: Know when courts stay proceedings, remove arbitrators, and grounds to set aside or modify awards. Apply to partnership/company and commercial disputes.
keyTakeaways: Arbitration Act 1940 governs (domestic) with court supervision.
Misconduct or jurisdictional errors can vitiate awards.
Arbitration agreement must be in writing; scope matters.

notes.title: Competition Law: Prohibited Agreements, Abuse of Dominance, Merger Control
notes.content: Explain Section 4 (anti-competitive agreements), Section 3 (abuse), and merger approvals. Use local market examples for analysis.
keyTakeaways: Competition Commission of Pakistan enforces CA 2010.
Leniency, exemptions, and penalties are examinable.
Merger review: thresholds, timelines, and second-phase scrutiny.

notes.title: Electronic Transactions & E-Signatures; Electronic Funds Transfers
notes.content: ETO 2002 gives legal recognition to electronic records/signatures. PS&EFT Act 2007 regulates payment systems and consumer protections (unauthorized transfers, disclosures).
keyTakeaways: E-records/e-signatures have evidentiary recognition under ETO.
SBP regulates payment systems; operators designated and supervised.
Know consumer liability rules for unauthorized EFT and disclosure duties.

resources.title: Payment Systems & Electronic Fund Transfers Act, 2007 (SBP PDF)

notes.title: Consumer Protection (Provincial Acts) & Contract Remedies
notes.content: Although federal framework is limited, provinces (e.g., Punjab) have consumer statutes. Link exam answers to contractual remedies plus special consumer forums where applicable.
keyTakeaways: Punjab CPA 2005 creates specific rights, forums, and penalties.
Use consumer law to complement Sale of Goods warranty/defect scenarios.
Discuss evolving jurisprudence and enforcement challenges.

resources.title: Academic Review — Consumer Protection in Pakistan

notes.title: Currency, Paper Money & SBP Context (for NI & policy questions)
notes.content: Understand why only SBP can issue bearer notes and policy backdrop for negotiable instruments and payments.
keyTakeaways: State Bank of Pakistan Act confers issuance/monetary authority.
Link to NI Act questions on bearer instruments and policy rationale.

resources.title: State Bank of Pakistan Act, 1956 (SBP official)

notes.title: Exam Strategy: Syllabus Mapping + Past Papers + Video Aids
notes.content: Start with FPSC syllabus, then solve descriptive papers 2024–2021 and older (2000–2015). Supplement with concise lectures/playlists for revision and paper-attempt tips.
keyTakeaways: Build notes per syllabus headings (Contract → Sales → Partnership → Company → NI → Arbitration → Competition → E-Transactions/EFT → Consumer).
Practice problem-style answers with statutory citations.
Use solved-paper videos only as a check; rely on statutes.
